description: From Anglo-Norman mortmayn, morte meyn, from Old French mortes meins, after Late Latin phrase mortua manus. See Latin mortuus (“dead”) + manus (“hand”).

entries.meaning: (law) The perpetual, inalienable possession of lands by a corporation or non-personal entity such as a church.
examples: [W]e do hereby grant our especial license and authority unto all and every person  […]  to grant sell alien and convey in mortmain unto and to the use of the said Society and their successors  […]

[…] ; and some part of that influence [of the government], which would otherwise have been possessed as in a sort of mortmain and unalienable domain, returned again to the great ocean from whence it arose,  […]
